CAPTION FIG1.png: 'Figure 1: The Weaver model outlined both the semantic and technical problems of communication (Shannon and Weaver 1963, pp. 98, 115–16)\n\n'
CAPTION FIG2.png: 'Figure 2: Sample abstract highlighting four words for which ambiguity is measured. “Mechanical” and “properties” are measured as relatively precise while “investigate” and “morphology” are measured as relatively ambiguous (Brahimi et al. 1994).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG3.png: 'Figure 3: Three sample DAGs and their entropy measures (\\(H\\)). Trees such as the leftmost graph always have the theoretical minimum entropy of zero. The center and right graphs have the same numbers of edges, but the center graph has much more distinct clusters of intercepting articles and thus a lower entropy.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG4.png: 'Fig. 4.--A sample of terms and their distribution of ambiguity across various disciplines. The circles represent the mean ambiguity of a term in a field, and the scattered dots represent the actual individual ambiguity of each term (randomly jittered in the vertical dimension for greater visual discrimination).\n\n'
CAPTION FIGB1.png: 'Fig. 1: Example posterior distribution of entropy. The dotted (left) line represents the ML estimate of entropy based solely on the observed frequencies.\n\n'
CAPTION FIGC1.png: 'Figure 1: Left panel: Scatter plot with ambiguity as measured by the model (standardized to have a mean of 0.0 and a standard deviation of 1.0) on the horizontal axis and user ratings of ambiguity on a 0–6 scale on the vertical axis. Right panel: Marginal distribution of user-rated ambiguity.\n\n'
CAPTION TABC2.png: 'TABLE C2\n\nPoint Estimates and Confidence Intervals for Model Comticients and Random-Effect Standard Dividations'
